Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Collaborative Research: Multireference Studies of Organic Polyradicals, Radical Reactions and Graphene Nanoribbons
Award.AbstractNarration:
Carol Parish at the University of Richmond and Hans Lischka at Texas Tech University are supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational methods program to perform theoretical investigations of the structures, reactivities and excited states of di-, tetra- and poly-radical molecules important to understanding reaction mechanisms, pyrolysis and combustion of alternative fuels, anticancer antibiotics and graphene nanodevices. A fundamental understanding of the proper physical characterization of polyradicals is critically important for the further development of multireference (MR) electronic structure theory as well as understanding and controlling chemical phenomenon involving these open-shell intermediates. This proposal focuses on utilizing MR methods (MR-CI, MR-AQCC, CASPT2) to study 1.) model systems such as the geometries and excites states of o-, m- and p-benzyne, 2.) diradical intermediates found in the pyrolyis of asphaltene heteroaromatic compounds, 3.) novel electrocyclization reactions producing diradical intermediates that may function as anticancer antibiotics, 4.) reactions involving tetraradicals and the role that through-bond coupling plays in radical electron interaction, 5.) diradical and multiradical defects in graphene and to benchmark these MR methods against DFT results and 6.) developing input and analysis tools for the COLUMBUS package to facilitate the use of these highly correlated MR methods by the chemical community including undergraduate students.

The ability to characterize properly open-shell polyradical species and the corresponding investigation of novel cyclization reactions holds significant promise for advancing the fields of MR theoretical chemistry, mechanistic organic chemistry, materials design and drug optimization. The proposal delineates several carefully conceived theoretical experiments designed to be performed by undergraduate researchers, graduate students and post-baccalaureate or post-doctoral fellows. This will create a community of scientists focusing on the proper characterization of interesting polyradical species using state-of-the-art electronic structure methods. Students at all levels will learn the details of computational quantum mechanics, spectroscopy and methods development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF final outcomes report

Over the last 7 years, the Parish laboratory at the University of Richmond has published 17 peer-reviewed publications and trained 44 undergraduate students. These students have been responsible for more than 100 scientific presentations at national chemistry meetings.

Intellectual Merit: Over the last 7 years, we have completed a number of projects related to better understanding the behavior of aromatic radical, diradical and polyradical species. These radical containing molecules are relatively stable due to their aromatic nature yet also highly reactive because they contain unpaired electrons. To date, very little information is available regarding polyradical chemistry as such radicals are difficult to characterize experimentally and theoretically. Very sophisticated theoretical methods are necessary in order to capture the underlying physics of these molecules. Understanding radical chemistry is important, as it will allow us to make advances in photonics, materials design, synthetic chemistry and molecular magnets. The ability to characterize properly open-shell polyradical species and the corresponding investigation of novel cyclization reactions holds significant promise for advancing the fields of polyradical chemistry, mechanistic organic chemistry, materials design, drug optimization and understanding the molecular components of cigarette smoke and asphaltenes from alternative energy sources such as oil shale. The work published using NSF-RUI support has contributed to further understanding of polyradical behavior as well as the performance of multi-reference theoretical methods. 

Broader Impacts:  The NSF-RUI funds supported many carefully conceived theoretical experiments performed by undergraduate researchers. The PI has a strong record of mentoring undergraduate students in publishable research, national presentations and career advancement in the sciences and this granting period was no different. 44 undergraduate students receiving training in computational chemistry. Underrepresented students participated in significant numbers. The NSF-RUI funding was used to create a community of scientists focusing on the proper characterization of interesting polyradical species using state-of-the-art electronic structure methods.  Students at all levels mastered the details of computational quantum mechanics and spectroscopy. The broader impacts of the reported outcomes include a significant number of students from groups underrepresented in chemistry, including women and students of color, had the opportunity to work side-by-side with the PIs on meaningful research projects in a highly mentored research environment. In addition, students received, and benefitted from, intensive training in computational chemistry, and, from this experience, they developed skill sets that will serve them well in their post-baccalaureate, post-doctoral or independent scientific careers. 

 

 


Last Modified: 04/30/2018
Modified by: Carol A Parish
